title-group.article-title: Is CTKUB the gold standard in assessing flank pain with diagnostic uncertainty? A one-year review of 228 cases

contrib-group.aff: Department of Urology, Southport and Formby District General Hospital, UK

author-notes.corresp: James Dyer, Department of Urology, Southport and Formby District General Hospital, Town Lane, Kew, Southport PR8 6PN, UK. Email: james.dyer@nhs.net

abstract.p: The use of computed tomography of the kidneys, ureters and bladder (CTKUB) in a "renal colic pathway" has been reported to yield high diagnosis rates and also identifies other non-urological pathology accounting for patients’ symptoms. Our study explores the diagnostic yield of CTKUB as the first-line investigation for suspected renal colic with regard to urolithiasis and additional findings. All CTKUB performed in cases of suspected renal colic were extracted from our radiology database from 1 April 2010 to 1 April 2011. Extracted information included: demographics, the department ordering the investigation, presence of ureteric calculi, presence of renal calculi and any additional findings that could account for patients’ symptoms, or otherwise. During the study 228 CTKUB were performed. The diagnosis rate of ureteric calculi was 33.7%. In the absence of a ureteric stone, additional findings as well as alternative diagnoses were higher (additional finding 49.7% (n=75) vs. 35% (n=27); alternative diagnosis 33.1% (n=50) vs. 15.6% (n=12) p < 0.05). In patients with ureteric calculi, the alternative diagnosis yield of 15.6% falls within the range of that previously documented. This study illustrates that when diagnostic clarity is not reached, CTKUB is being overused. This leads to unnecessary radiation exposure and resource wastage.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Since the first description of the role played by unenhanced computed tomography of the kidneys, ureters and bladder (CTKUB) in the rapid diagnosis of acute renal colic in 1995,1 its usage has risen in popularity. The use of CTKUB as a first-line investigation in a “renal colic pathway” has been reported to yield high diagnosis rates and also identifies other non-urological pathology accounting for patients’ symptoms.2–7 Despite its widespread uptake and European guidelines recommending this as the first-line investigation for acute renal colic, some authors harbour reservations over the development of “indication creep”.4 The rise in popularity of CTKUB over time has led to a broadening of the indications from its intended original usage in suspected ureteric calculi to an investigation for non-specific flank pain.4 Concerns have also been raised over the use of CTKUB in women of childbearing age, in whom diagnosis rates have been reported as being lower.8 Furthermore, because CTKUB involves higher radiation dosage than intravenous urography (IVU) and ultrasound scan (USS), this further calls into question its justification in this group of patients.
Our study explores the diagnostic yield of CTKUB as the first-line investigation for suspected renal colic with regard to urolithiasis and incidental pathology.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: All non-contrast CTKUB reports were extracted from our radiology database from 1 April 2010 to 1 April 2011. Scans were included in the subsequent analysis if the clinical information entered on the request form contained the phrases “renal colic”, “ureteric colic” or “acute flank pain”. Extracted information included: patient demographics, the presence, site and size of ureteric calculi and the presence of renal calculi. Urine microscopy was also reviewed and patients were stratified according to the presence or absence of microscopic haematuria. Any additional radiological findings were categorised as either alternative diagnosis that could account for the patients’ symptoms, or incidental findings that could not but were clinically significant.
In our centre a CTKUB could be requested in one of three ways:

list-item.p: Requested and performed in the emergency department if within office hours as part of the renal colic pathway (Appendix 1).
Requested by the on-call urology team and performed in the next available scanning session if either outside of office hours or unable to perform the same day.
Requested by another inpatient staff member (general medical, general surgical) in suspected renal colic that has been inappropriately referred.

sec.p: This information was also included in our analysis. Statistical significance was determined using Fisher’s exact test with 95% confidence. Ethical approval was not sought, as it was thought not to be required for this retrospective analysis.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: During the study period 228 CTKUB were performed; 57.0% of our patients were male and 44.7% were aged 50 or older. All the scans were performed during office hours and none were conducted over the weekend.

Overall, a diagnosis of ureteric calculus was made in 33.7% of patients. The distribution with respect to site and size are indicated in Table 1. CTKUB ordered from the emergency department had a significantly higher diagnosis yield than those ordered by either a urologist or other hospital departments (Table 2).

sec.p: The overall rate of ipsilateral and contralateral renal calculi diagnosis was 25.9% and 19.7%, respectively; this was significantly higher if a ureteric stone had been identified in the same scan (37.6% and 40.3%, p < 0.05). Single and multiple renal tract stones were found independent of ureteric stone size (< 5 mm 40.7% vs. > 5 mm 58%, p = 0.16).
There was no significant difference between the rates of renal or ureteric calculi diagnosis in patients when stratified by age (> 50 years 36.3% vs. < 50 years 31.7%, p = 0.48).

Data were available on 133 patients with regard to the presence or absence of microscopic haematuria. In the remaining patients there was either no urinalysis documented in the request form or case notes or no microscopy performed, therefore we could not reliably confirm the presence or absence of haematuria. The presence of microscopic haematuria predicted the presence of a ureteric stone (47.7% vs. 25.9%, p < 0.05). However, in women of childbearing age this was not the case (20% vs. 14.3%, p = 0.51).

An additional finding was present in 44.7% (n=102) of patients. These were further stratified into alternative diagnoses that could contribute to or be the sole cause of patient symptoms (26.8%) (n=61), or incidental findings thought not to be contributing to patient symptoms but still clinically significant (18.0%) (n=41).
Patients older than 50 years of age had a higher rate of additional findings and alternative diagnosis; however, there was no significant difference between the rate of incidental findings (Table 3).

sec.p: In the absence of a ureteric stone the presence of an incidental finding and an alternative diagnosis was higher (additional finding 49.7% (n=75) vs. 35% (n=27); alternative diagnosis 33.1% (n=50) vs. 15.6% (n=12) p < 0.05). In the cohort of patients identified as having a ureteric calculus, the alternative diagnosis yield of 15.6% falls within the range of that previously documented2–7 (Table 5).

sec.p: Of the additional findings, 24.2% (n=29) were renal and 75.8% (n=91) were extra-renal. The renal findings included simple and complex cysts, renal and ureteric cancers, renal infarcts and pelviureteric junction (PUJ) obstruction. Extra-renal additional findings included gastrointestinal (20.8%), hepatobiliary (17.5%), musculoskeletal (11.7%), gynaecological (9.2%), respiratory (4.2%), vascular (1.7%), and other (10.7%) (Figure 1 and Table 6).

sec.p: Of the total 120 (102 patients) additional findings, 47.5% (n=57) were diagnoses in which an ultrasound scan is the recommended first-line investigation and 20% (n=24) were a finding in which contrast CT is the recommended first-line investigation.
No abnormal finding was recorded in 21.5% (n=49) cases.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The diagnosis rates of ureteric calculi in our study are low compared to other studies2–4 and, in the absence of a ureteric calculus, incidental findings and alternative diagnoses are more common. The confirmation of small calculi having a predilection for the distal ureter and all calculi being more common in males support the external validity of the study population.

The delay in scanning (and presumed consequently higher rate of spontaneous stone passage) inherent in a service that best runs during office hours alone may, in part, account for the overall low diagnosis rate of ureteric calculi and significantly lower diagnosis rate in scans requested by the urology team. Although the combined analysis of this cohort introduces heterogeneity and weakness to our study, the delay to scan should not influence the rate of additional findings and alternative diagnosis that are particularly high and suggest an alternative reason.

Our interpretation of the results is that when diagnostic clarity is not reached, and an alternative diagnosis to ureteric calculus may have higher pre-test probability, CTKUB is being overused. This leads to unnecessary radiation exposure and resource wastage. Although this in part could be explained by the frequency with which patients were undergoing CTKUB in the absence of haematuria, the diagnosis rate of a ureteric calculus remains low in the presence of microscopic haematuria.

Whilst some authors maintain that the high incidence of alternative diagnosis is a strength of using CTKUB in the assessment of suspected acute renal colic,3 our study highlights that indication creep and the incomplete appraisal of pre-test probability of a range of diagnoses may account for this.

Furthermore, an appraisal of the most appropriate first-line investigation for the alternative findings shows that the vast majority of such findings are best characterised with USS, plain radiology or contrast CT scan. The potential need for further imaging compounds the issues of resource wastage and consequent radiation exposure. Interpretation of the significance of incidental diagnoses on CTKUB must bear in mind its specific limitations, which include a reduced field of examination and a reduced ability, when compared to enhanced CT, to differentiate visceral ischaemia, infarction and mass lesions. To our knowledge there is no available literature detailing the sensitivity and specificity of CTKUB for the range of incidental diagnosis it uncovers. Consequently, one must be aware of such uncertainty when basing management decisions, not regarding lithiasis, on the findings of a CTKUB.

We propose that if CTKUB is to be employed in a centre as the principal investigation in a renal colic pathway, it should be done so when a ureteric calculus is the most likely diagnosis, and the practice of using CTKUB as a triage for flank pain should be reconsidered. Centres should regularly review their practice to avoid such indication creep. Furthermore, the practice of using CTKUB in women of childbearing age is under review in our centre, and alternative imaging strategies are being sought.
